Lessons for IT Project Manager Efficacy: A Review of the Literature Associated with Project Success
Hyvä kirjallisuuskatsaus, mutta keskittyy ehkä liikaa tutkielman kannalta ei-relevantteihin asioihin.
Plan on reading it 4-5 times. The first time it is going to be a whole bunch of new
The first reading is to inventory the words, where they are used, and how important they are. Don't try to understand except in the
The second time you can start to make some sense out of it because hopefully you think you might understand 1/3- 1/2 of the words.

Now look up some definitions. Google might help, otherwise the difficult word(s) might be cited, in which case you need to read the abstract of the relevant paper (only enough to get a definition of what the word might mean).
The third time you read it, you should know 1/2 to 2/3rds of the words and be able to make good connections between them, you start to see the ideas take shape.
The fourth read you fill in the gaps from the outline you made in the third read.
opintoja enemmän tai vähemmän aiheeseen liittyen.
-kurssi, jolla artikkeleiden lukua opetettiin aika hyvin
, sitten kokonaan ilman että äännät päässä)
, pitänyt lyhyen tauon ja lukenut koko tekstin. Näen sen hyödyllisenä, sillä tästä alkaa oppimaan sen miltä
A model of critical success factors for software projects
On kerätty kasa (relevanttia?) kirjallisuutta, ja jos artikkeli mainitsee menestystekijän
kuinka monta kertaa tahansa, saa se yhden
viittauksen (pisteen) artikkelista. Kaikki nämä menestystekijät on koottu taulukkoon, jossa ne on sijoitettu erilaisten kategorioiden alle. Nämä kategoriat
kirjoittajan jotenkin kirjallisuuden pohjalta luomat. Sitten jokaisen kategorian top 5 menestystekijää sanotaan olevan relevantteja ohjelmistoprojekteille.
koen hyvin vääräksi arvostaa menestystekijöitä jotenkin viittausten perusteella – sanotaan että meillä on joku suosittu lähde
tämän ns. suosittu, ei välttämättä tieteellinen lähde ohjaa hyvin paljon ihmisten käsityksiä
ja siten tutkimusta aiheesta – onko joku asia arvokas koska siitä puhutaan paljon?
ilmeisesti muun tutkimuksen pohjalta tehtyä tutkimusta (eli kirjallisuuskatsausta)
miksi joidenkin tiettyjen kategorioiden korostaminen nähdään arvokkaana?

ä tutkimus aiheuttaa pahoinvointia – muihin tutkimuksiin viitataan luettelomaisesti ”he tarkastelivat x asiaa ja tuloksina olivat x menestystekijää” – onko
asialla arvoa, koska joku toinen on sen sanonut? Mutta toisaalta ehkä nyt menen turhan syvälle
onhan tuo kai tällaisen toissijaisen tutkimuksen luonne.
että tämä olisi jotenkin kovempaa tiedettä.

määritelmät, ja esittää sitten ”niiden perusteella” omat kategoriansa. Olisin toivonut tähän

Määritelmiä onnistuneelle projektille on monia. Erään määritelmän mukaan projekti
on onnistunut, jos siinä on pidetty tehokas aikataulu.
[idea siitä, kuinka onnistumiseen vaikuttavia tekijöitä voidaan luetella loputtomasti ja niitä vastaan ei luultavasti oltaisi]
Toisaalta onnistumisen määrittelyyn vaikuttaa myös tarkasteluaikavälin pituus.

Lauseen ”tehokas aikataulu takaa projektin onnistumisen” voi ymmärtää niin, että työntekijöistä pitää saada kaikki irti saatavissa oleva teho irti – joka voi lyhyellä aikavälillä toimia. Toisaalta mikäli yritys alkaa saamaan huonon maineen
ankarana työnantajana, ei se välttämättä ole enää houkutteleva työpaikka

Critical success factors can be described as characteristics, conditions, or variables that can have a significant impact on the success of the project when properly sustained, maintained, or managed [17].

According to Eisenhardt [22], the case study research is necessary ‘‘at times when little is known about a phenomenon, current perspectives seem inadequate because there have little empirical substantiation.’’
the degree to which the projects accomplished their schedule, cost, quality, and customer satisfaction goals

Some interviewees believe that there is an inflection point in this standardization increase. Specifically, increasing the degree of standardization of the factors to a certain point may lead to the increase in project success. Increasing the degree of standardization of the factors beyond that point tends to lower project success. Where this inflection point exactly is appears to be company-specific, meaning that it varies from company to company.

When consistently applied, this standardized set would help detect how well the project strategy works and where and why it is flawed. It can also help devise actions to eliminate the flaws, hence increasing chances for success.

One way of addressing the issue of the definition of project success is by viewing the concept as consisting of two parts: project management success and project success (

Project management success represents the internal, rather short-term view of the project, with a focus on the successful accomplishment of cost, time and quality objectives, the manner in which the project management process was conducted, and the satisfaction of stakeholder needs (internal efficiency) (
on the other hand, focuses on the triple constraint (budget, schedule and specifications) (Chaos Report, 2015;

Thomas and Fernandez (2007) found three categories of project success:
project management success (on-time, on-budget, sponsor satisfaction, steering group satisfaction, project team satisfaction, customer/user satisfaction,
technical success (customer/user satisfaction, stakeholder satisfaction, system implementation, met requirements, system quality, system use) and
business success (business continuity, met business objectives, delivery of benefits).

Factors Affecting the Successful Realisation of Benefits from Systems Development Projects: Findings from Three Case Studies

As noted by Cobb (1996), in his now much quoted paradox: ‘we know why [information systems] projects fail, and we know how to prevent their failure – so why do they still fail?’

Plugging such a Bayesian model into a decision theoretic framework, the effects of various decision scenarios
can be evaluated beforehand, facilitating more rational decision making (Resnik, 1987).
Much has been written about success factors for project management. The same cannot be said about IT project management in specific.
Coordinators of projects need to consider an almost endless amount of technical, market-related, and organizational interdependencies.
(2004) make a profound contribution to the discussion of project success factors by noting tha
t independent variables for project success vary with the stages of the project life cycle.

All of the above consider projects in general rather than specific types of projects. However, as the present study focuses exclusively on IT projects, only research specifically about IT projects will be included in the literature review presented in Section 3.
The Standish Group (2009) fails to describe their research methodology in a comprehensive way, the size of the study makes it impossible to overlook.

In many cases, it is reasonable to assume that factors are independent, but this is not always the case. One project manager could for instance promote extensive use of risk analysis in the project planning, as could any of the project team members. Therefore, the impact of factors such as risk analysis and top management support depend to some extent on other factors.
The model presented in this article is based on theoretical expertise on IT project management, thereby providing a general quantification of the success factors.

Drawing upon this tri-focal lens, we propose a shift in focus on success to the intersection, or “sweet spot of project manager efficacy.”

Our long list of references highlights that this phenomenon is confounded by the fact that reference to “project success” is often a comprehensive term that includes factors related to project outcomes, the project management methodology, and the project manager’s (person’s) proficiency in using project management techniques, and efficacy in managing across this entire range of issues.
As such, one of our key findings highlighted in the literature is the repeated adage that the only agreement on definitions of success as related to projects and project management is that
An additional complicating factor is that different stakeholder groups may define success differently for the same projects

Among the first to argue that we should distinguish between project success and project management success, De Wit (1988) pointed out that the objectives for projects are not the same as objectives for the project management activities, and may even have a hierarchy of priorities.
Meeting schedules, budget, and technical performance measures—referred to as “the iron triangle” (de Wit, 1988)
moneskohan vaihtoehtoinen nimi tämä on tälle.

Despite almost 30 years of lessons learned, his advice for post-implementation audits should be heeded “not so much to determine if absolute terms the success or failure but to identify what went right and what went wrong and why (p. 169).”

it makes sense that there is not a single definition of project success or a universal set of criteria that one can use to predict project success or the associated skills that lead to it.

As shown in Table 2, this debate has been implicit (if not explicit), in most of the research on the many potential factors that lead to project success. A weakness of many of these studies is that they present lists of success factors without sharing context-specific elements.
We observed that this subjective view has evolved, leading to categories of factors.

and Müller’s (2005) analysis suggests an evolution in project success related research, they still highlight that project success has both an objective and subjective component and different stakeholder groups interpret project success differently.

The factors influencing project success measurements and perceptions are often in conflict. For example, meeting a budgetary or schedule constraint can have a negative impact on satisfying technical or functional requirements.
The literature treats the project management process as a contributing factor to project
de Wit (1988): project management can contribute to project success; however, effective project management cannot prevent project failure.
Interestingly, neither the research nor the project management standards provide guidance on how or when to acquire or develop these valuable skills.

We conclude that rather than studying what constitutes project success, project management success, or even project manager success, research should focus on what contextual factors or attributes influence project manager efficacy, considering the importance of both the hard skills and soft skills over time as the make-up of the sweet spot shifts.

Instead, scholars outline the seminal research related to project management, or combined project management theory and refer to con tributing theories. Of the research with atheoretical basis, there are trends in using organizational theories, management theories, or leadership theories, which support the observation that project managers must be generalists in management and leadership and specialists in project management application (McHenry, 2008).
One message that has been consistent as research has evolved is that project managers and IT project managers must understand that project
success is a perception. Satisfying a
may not address either process or outcome expectations.
Our review supports that static checklists of skills or knowledge miss the point.
We have a wealth of research on hard skills or hard metrics, but a shortage of literature on soft skills and how business managers, IT managers, and project managers perceive them.

Regardless of the methodologies used, simply repeating studies about project outcomes or project management techniques will add little to our understanding if we ignore the decision-making, interpersonal abilities, and contextual challenges in applying various techniques that are often missing in current research.
[1] as ‘‘a temporary endeavor undertaken, to create a unique product or service’’.
Earned Value (EV) is the classical project control method used for monitoring two dimensions: time and cost.
